definitions.definition: to press something so hard that it is damaged or loses its shape; to press somebody so hard that they are injured

examples.text: The car was completely crushed under the truck.
Several people were **crushed to death** in the accident.
His hand was badly crushed in the accident.
He was crushed beneath a bus.
She was crushed between two cars.
insects that had been crushed underfoot

definitions.definition: to break something into small pieces or into a powder by pressing hard

examples.text: Add two cloves of crushed garlic.
They crush the olives with a heavy wooden press.
Crush the biscuits finely before adding them to the mixture.

definitions.definition: to push or press somebody/something into a small space

examples.text: Over twenty prisoners were crushed into a small dark cell.
She was crushed against the wall.

definitions.definition: to make something full of folds or lines; to become full of folds or lines

examples.text: She crushed the scrap of paper in her hand.
The crisp paper crushed like eggshells in his fingers.

definitions.definition: to use violent methods to defeat people who are opposing you

examples.text: The army was sent in to crush the rebellion.
Attempts to crush serious popular unrest led to civil war.
The government succeeded in crushing the military rising.

definitions.definition: to destroy somebody’s confidence or happiness

examples.text: She felt completely crushed by the teacher's criticism.
He always has this fantastic energy. Nothing can crush him.
Their new self-confidence could not be crushed.

definitions.definition: to do something very well or be very successful

examples.text: She got up on stage and absolutely crushed it—the audience was going wild!
His latest film is crushing it at the box office.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French cruissir, ‘gnash (teeth) or crack’, of unknown origin.
